title: Columbus Day
description: Commemorate Christopher Columbus' historic voyage to the Americas on Columbus Day. This federal holiday marks the anniversary of Columbus' landing in 1492, celebrating Italian-American heritage and the spirit of exploration. Learn about the historical significance, discover local parades and festivals, and explore the complex legacy of this pivotal moment in world history.
howToCelebrate: Attend local Columbus Day parades and festivals celebrating Italian-American culture. Visit museums or historical sites related to exploration and maritime history. Learn about the complex history of European exploration and its impact on indigenous peoples. Enjoy Italian-American cuisine and cultural events. Read books or watch documentaries about the Age of Exploration.
funFacts: Columbus never actually set foot on mainland North America
His ships were the Niña, Pinta, and Santa María
Columbus Day became a federal holiday in 1937
Many states now celebrate Indigenous Peoples' Day instead
Columbus made four voyages to the Americas between 1492 and 1504

title: Halloween
description: Get ready for the spookiest night of the year! Halloween brings out the kid in all of us with costumes, trick-or-treating, haunted houses, and pumpkin carving. From ancient Celtic traditions to modern celebrations, discover the rich history behind this beloved holiday. Whether you're planning a party, decorating your home, or just enjoying some candy, Halloween is all about fun, creativity, and a little bit of fright!
howToCelebrate: Carve pumpkins with creative designs and display them on your porch. Dress up in costumes and go trick-or-treating or attend a Halloween party. Decorate your home with spooky decorations like cobwebs, skeletons, and jack-o'-lanterns. Watch classic horror movies or family-friendly Halloween films. Visit a haunted house or corn maze for thrills. Hand out candy to trick-or-treaters in your neighborhood.
funFacts: Halloween originated from the ancient Celtic festival of Samhain over 2,000 years ago
Americans spend over $9 billion on Halloween each year
The largest pumpkin ever recorded weighed 2,624 pounds
Black cats were once believed to be witches' familiars
The tradition of trick-or-treating began in medieval Europe

title: Veterans Day
description: Honor those who served our country on Veterans Day! This federal holiday pays tribute to all American military veterans who have bravely served in the armed forces. Attend local ceremonies, visit veterans' memorials, or simply thank a veteran for their service. Learn about the history of this important day and discover ways to support veterans in your community.
howToCelebrate: Attend a Veterans Day parade or ceremony in your community. Visit a veterans' memorial or cemetery to pay your respects. Thank veterans you know personally for their service. Donate to organizations that support veterans and their families. Learn about the history of Veterans Day and the sacrifices made by military personnel. Fly the American flag at half-mast until noon, then full-staff.
funFacts: Veterans Day was originally called Armistice Day and marked the end of World War I
The date November 11th was chosen because WWI ended on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month
There are over 18 million veterans living in the United States today
Veterans Day became a federal holiday in 1938
The holiday was temporarily moved to the fourth Monday in October from 1971-1977

title: Thanksgiving Day
description: Gather with family and friends to give thanks on Thanksgiving Day! This beloved American holiday is all about gratitude, delicious food, and spending quality time with loved ones. From the traditional turkey dinner to football games and parades, Thanksgiving brings communities together to celebrate the blessings in our lives. Discover new recipes, learn about the holiday's history, and create lasting memories.
howToCelebrate: Prepare a traditional Thanksgiving feast with turkey, stuffing, cranberry sauce, and pumpkin pie. Go around the table and share what you're grateful for this year. Watch the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade or football games. Volunteer at a local food bank or homeless shelter. Take a family walk or play outdoor games together. Send thank-you notes to people who have made a difference in your life.
funFacts: The first Thanksgiving was celebrated in 1621 and lasted three days
Americans eat about 46 million turkeys on Thanksgiving
The Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade started in 1924
Thanksgiving became a national holiday in 1863 when Abraham Lincoln declared it
The average Thanksgiving meal contains about 3,000 calories

title: Hanukkah 2025
description: Celebrate the Festival of Lights! Hanukkah commemorates the miracle of the oil that lasted eight days in the ancient Temple. Light the menorah, enjoy traditional foods like latkes and sufganiyot, play dreidel games, and exchange gifts with family and friends. Learn about the rich traditions, history, and meaning behind this beautiful Jewish holiday that brings light and joy to the darkest time of year.
howToCelebrate: Light the menorah each night for eight nights, adding one candle each day. Enjoy traditional Hanukkah foods like latkes (potato pancakes) and sufganiyot (jelly donuts). Play dreidel games with family and friends. Exchange small gifts each night of Hanukkah. Learn about the history and meaning of Hanukkah through books or online resources. Attend community Hanukkah celebrations or host your own.
funFacts: Hanukkah means 'dedication' in Hebrew
The holiday commemorates the rededication of the Second Temple in Jerusalem
Hanukkah lasts for eight days and nights
The menorah used during Hanukkah is called a hanukkiah and has nine branches
Hanukkah is not mentioned in the Hebrew Bible but is described in the Talmud

title: Christmas Eve
description: The magic is in the air on Christmas Eve! This special night is filled with anticipation, wonder, and the joy of giving. From hanging stockings and leaving cookies for Santa to attending midnight mass or enjoying a quiet family dinner, Christmas Eve traditions vary but all share the same spirit of love and togetherness. Create lasting memories and embrace the wonder of the season.
howToCelebrate: Hang stockings by the fireplace and leave cookies and milk for Santa. Attend Christmas Eve church services or watch them online. Enjoy a special family dinner together. Read Christmas stories or watch classic holiday movies. Drive around to look at Christmas light displays in your neighborhood. Spend quality time with loved ones and create new traditions.
funFacts: Christmas Eve is celebrated on December 24th in most Western countries
The tradition of hanging stockings comes from the story of St. Nicholas
Many families open one present on Christmas Eve
Christmas Eve is often considered more important than Christmas Day in some cultures
The tradition of leaving cookies for Santa started in the 1930s

title: Christmas Day
description: Merry Christmas! Celebrate the most wonderful time of the year with family, friends, and the joy of giving. From opening presents under the tree to enjoying a festive feast, Christmas Day is about love, gratitude, and creating precious memories. Whether you're celebrating the religious significance or simply enjoying the magic of the season, may your day be filled with peace, joy, and happiness.
howToCelebrate: Wake up early to open presents with family and friends. Attend Christmas church services or watch them online. Prepare and enjoy a traditional Christmas dinner with loved ones. Watch classic Christmas movies like 'It's a Wonderful Life' or 'A Christmas Story'. Call or video chat with family members who can't be there in person. Give back by volunteering at a soup kitchen or donating to charity.
funFacts: Christmas trees were first decorated in 16th century Germany
Santa Claus is based on Saint Nicholas, a 4th-century Greek bishop
The first Christmas card was sent in 1843
Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer was created for a department store in 1939
Christmas is celebrated by over 2 billion people worldwide

title: New Year's Eve
description: Ring in the New Year with style and celebration! New Year's Eve is the perfect time to reflect on the past year and look forward to new beginnings. From glamorous parties and fireworks displays to quiet gatherings with loved ones, celebrate the end of one year and the start of another. Make resolutions, count down to midnight, and toast to new possibilities and fresh starts.
howToCelebrate: Attend a New Year's Eve party or host your own celebration with friends and family. Watch the ball drop in Times Square or find a local fireworks display. Make New Year's resolutions and write them down. Toast with champagne or sparkling cider at midnight. Reflect on the past year and set goals for the new one. Share a kiss with someone special at midnight for good luck.
funFacts: The Times Square ball drop tradition started in 1907
The first New Year's Eve celebration was held in ancient Babylon 4,000 years ago
Eating black-eyed peas on New Year's Eve is thought to bring good luck
The tradition of making resolutions dates back to ancient Rome
New Year's Eve is celebrated at different times around the world due to time zones

title: Presidents Day
description: Honor the legacy of American presidents on Presidents Day! This federal holiday celebrates the contributions and leadership of all U.S. presidents, with special recognition for George Washington and Abraham Lincoln. Learn about presidential history, visit historical sites, and reflect on the importance of leadership and public service in American democracy.
howToCelebrate: Visit presidential libraries, monuments, or historical sites. Read biographies of American presidents and learn about their contributions. Watch documentaries about presidential history and American government. Attend local Presidents Day events and parades. Discuss the importance of civic engagement and democratic values.
funFacts: Presidents Day was originally established to honor George Washington's birthday
It's officially called 'Washington's Birthday' at the federal level
The holiday was moved to the third Monday in February in 1971
Four U.S. presidents were born in February: Washington, Lincoln, Reagan, and Harrison
Mount Rushmore features four presidents: Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt, and Lincoln

title: Labor Day
description: Celebrate the contributions of workers and the labor movement on Labor Day! This federal holiday honors the achievements of American workers and their role in building the nation's strength and prosperity. From its origins in the labor movement to modern celebrations, Labor Day marks the unofficial end of summer and recognizes the dignity of work.
howToCelebrate: Attend local Labor Day parades and festivals. Take time to appreciate the hard work of essential workers in your community. Learn about the history of the labor movement and workers' rights. Enjoy end-of-summer activities like barbecues, picnics, or beach trips. Support worker-friendly businesses and fair labor practices.
funFacts: Labor Day was first celebrated in 1882 in New York City
It became a federal holiday in 1894 after the Pullman Strike
Labor Day is celebrated on the first Monday in September
It traditionally marks the end of summer and the start of the school year
The first Labor Day parade had 10,000 workers marching in New York

title: Martin Luther King Jr. Day
description: Honor the legacy of civil rights leader Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on this federal holiday! This day celebrates Dr. King's contributions to the civil rights movement and his dream of equality and justice for all. Reflect on his powerful message of nonviolent resistance, love, and unity while continuing the work toward a more just and equitable society.
howToCelebrate: Participate in community service projects and volunteer activities. Attend MLK Day events, marches, or educational programs. Read Dr. King's speeches and writings, especially 'I Have a Dream'. Support civil rights organizations and social justice causes. Reflect on progress made and work still needed for equality.
funFacts: MLK Day became a federal holiday in 1983, first observed in 1986
It's the only federal holiday designated as a National Day of Service
Dr. King was the youngest person to receive the Nobel Peace Prize at age 35
His 'I Have a Dream' speech was largely improvised
All 50 states officially observe MLK Day as a holiday

title: Memorial Day
description: Honor and remember the brave men and women who died serving in the U.S. military on Memorial Day. This solemn federal holiday is a time to reflect on the ultimate sacrifice made by service members to protect our freedoms. From visiting cemeteries to participating in parades, join in remembering those who gave their lives for our country.
howToCelebrate: Visit national cemeteries or memorials to honor fallen service members. Participate in Memorial Day parades and ceremonies. Place flags or flowers on veterans' graves. Support military families and veteran organizations. Take a moment of silence at 3 PM for the National Moment of Remembrance.
funFacts: Memorial Day was originally called Decoration Day
It originated after the Civil War to honor Union soldiers
The holiday was moved to the last Monday in May in 1971
Wearing red poppies on Memorial Day honors fallen soldiers
The National Moment of Remembrance occurs at 3 PM local time

title: Independence Day
description: Celebrate America's birthday on Independence Day! This patriotic federal holiday commemorates the adoption of the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776, marking the birth of the United States of America. From fireworks and parades to barbecues and family gatherings, join in celebrating freedom, democracy, and the American spirit.
howToCelebrate: Watch fireworks displays and attend local parades. Host or attend a patriotic barbecue with friends and family. Display the American flag and wear red, white, and blue. Learn about American history and the founding fathers. Participate in community Independence Day events and festivals.
funFacts: The Declaration of Independence was actually signed on August 2, 1776
Americans consume 150 million hot dogs on July 4th
Three U.S. presidents died on July 4th: Adams, Jefferson, and Monroe
The first Fourth of July celebration at the White House was in 1801
Americans spend over $1 billion on fireworks each year

title: Earth Day
description: Show love for our planet on Earth Day! This global environmental movement encourages people to take action to protect the environment and address climate change. From tree planting to beach cleanups, Earth Day is about making positive changes for our planet and inspiring others to join the fight for a cleaner, healthier world.
howToCelebrate: Participate in local environmental cleanup activities. Plant trees or start a garden with native plants. Reduce energy consumption and adopt eco-friendly practices. Learn about climate change and environmental issues. Support environmental organizations and green initiatives.
funFacts: The first Earth Day was celebrated on April 22, 1970
Over 1 billion people participate in Earth Day activities worldwide
Earth Day led to the creation of the EPA and major environmental laws
The Earth Day flag features a photo of Earth from space
Earth Day is now celebrated in more than 190 countries

title: Flag Day
description: Honor the Stars and Stripes on Flag Day! This patriotic observance commemorates the adoption of the American flag on June 14, 1777. Learn about flag history, proper flag etiquette, and the symbolism behind the red, white, and blue. Display your flag proudly and reflect on what it represents - freedom, unity, and the American spirit.
howToCelebrate: Display the American flag at your home or business. Learn about proper flag etiquette and care. Attend Flag Day ceremonies or parades in your community. Teach children about the flag's history and symbolism. Share patriotic messages and flag facts on social media.
funFacts: The current 50-star flag was designed by a 17-year-old high school student
The flag has been modified 27 times since 1777
Flag Day became a national observance in 1916
The flag should never touch the ground
Betsy Ross is often credited with sewing the first American flag

title: Arbor Day
description: Plant trees and celebrate nature on Arbor Day! This environmental holiday encourages tree planting and forest conservation. Trees provide oxygen, clean air and water, prevent erosion, and create habitats for wildlife. Join community tree-planting events and learn about the vital role trees play in maintaining a healthy environment.
howToCelebrate: Plant a tree in your yard or participate in community tree-planting events. Learn about different tree species and their benefits. Support forest conservation organizations. Teach children about the importance of trees and forests. Share tree facts and environmental tips on social media.
funFacts: Arbor Day was first celebrated in Nebraska in 1872
Over 1 million trees were planted on the first Arbor Day
A single tree can absorb 48 pounds of CO2 per year
Trees can increase property values by up to 15%
The world loses about 18.7 million acres of forest annually

title: Juneteenth
description: Celebrate freedom and African American culture on Juneteenth! This federal holiday commemorates the end of slavery in the United States, marking when news of emancipation reached Texas on June 19, 1865. Learn about this important moment in American history, celebrate African American achievements, and reflect on the ongoing journey toward equality and justice.
howToCelebrate: Attend Juneteenth festivals and celebrations in your community. Learn about African American history and the end of slavery. Support Black-owned businesses and organizations. Read books by African American authors. Share the history and significance of Juneteenth on social media.
funFacts: Juneteenth became a federal holiday in 2021
Texas was the first state to make Juneteenth an official holiday in 1980
The Emancipation Proclamation was signed in 1863, but news didn't reach Texas until 1865
Juneteenth is also known as Freedom Day or Emancipation Day
Traditional Juneteenth foods include red drinks and foods symbolizing resilience

title: Valentine's Day
description: Celebrate love and romance on Valentine's Day! This beloved holiday is all about expressing affection for the special people in your life. From romantic dinners to heartfelt gifts, Valentine's Day reminds us to cherish our relationships and show appreciation for those we love most.
howToCelebrate: Plan a special date or romantic evening with your partner. Send Valentine's cards to friends and family. Give thoughtful gifts that show you care. Cook a special meal or order from a favorite restaurant. Express your love and appreciation for the important people in your life.
funFacts: Valentine's Day is named after Saint Valentine, a Roman priest
Americans spend about $20 billion on Valentine's Day gifts each year
The first Valentine's Day card was sent in 1415
Teachers receive the most Valentine's Day cards
The heart shape was first used as a symbol of love in the 13th century

title: New Year's Day
description: Ring in the new year with hope and celebration on New Year's Day! This global holiday marks the beginning of a fresh year and symbolizes new beginnings, resolutions, and opportunities. Whether you're making resolutions or simply celebrating with loved ones, embrace the promise of a new year ahead.
howToCelebrate: Make New Year's resolutions and set goals for the year ahead. Spend time with family and friends. Watch the Rose Parade or other New Year's celebrations. Reflect on the past year and plan for the future. Start new traditions or continue beloved ones.
funFacts: New Year's Day is celebrated on January 1st in most countries
The Times Square ball drop tradition started in 1907
About 45% of Americans make New Year's resolutions
The most popular resolution is to exercise more
New Year's Day is a federal holiday in the United States

title: St. Patrick's Day
description: Wear green and celebrate Irish culture on St. Patrick's Day! This festive holiday honors Saint Patrick, the patron saint of Ireland, and has become a global celebration of Irish heritage. From parades and traditional music to green beer and shamrocks, join in the fun and embrace the luck of the Irish!
howToCelebrate: Wear green clothing and accessories. Attend St. Patrick's Day parades and festivals. Enjoy traditional Irish food and drinks. Learn about Irish culture and history. Share St. Patrick's Day photos and celebrations on social media.
funFacts: St. Patrick's Day was originally a religious holiday in Ireland
The first St. Patrick's Day parade was held in New York City in 1762
The Chicago River is dyed green every St. Patrick's Day
St. Patrick is said to have driven snakes out of Ireland
The shamrock is a symbol of Ireland and the Holy Trinity

title: Easter
description: Celebrate renewal and new beginnings on Easter! This important Christian holiday commemorates the resurrection of Jesus Christ and is also celebrated as a spring festival of rebirth and renewal. From Easter eggs and bunnies to church services and family gatherings, embrace the joy and hope of this special season.
howToCelebrate: Attend Easter services or spend time in reflection. Participate in Easter egg hunts with family and children. Prepare traditional Easter meals and treats. Decorate Easter eggs and create spring crafts. Share Easter joy and spring photos on social media.
funFacts: Easter is celebrated on the first Sunday after the first full moon of spring
The Easter Bunny tradition originated in Germany
Americans consume over 16 billion jelly beans at Easter
The largest Easter egg hunt had over 500,000 eggs
Easter is the most important Christian holiday

title: Groundhog Day
description: Will he see his shadow? Celebrate Groundhog Day, America's quirky weather-predicting tradition! This beloved American holiday centers around Punxsutawney Phil and his annual weather forecast. From Pennsylvania to your local celebrations, join in the fun of this unique American tradition that brings communities together each February.
howToCelebrate: Watch the live Groundhog Day ceremony from Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania. Host a Groundhog Day party with weather-themed activities. Learn about the history and folklore of Groundhog Day. Visit local Groundhog Day celebrations in your area. Share Groundhog Day predictions and fun facts on social media.
funFacts: Groundhog Day has been celebrated in Punxsutawney since 1887
Punxsutawney Phil has been predicting weather for over 130 years
The tradition comes from German immigrants who brought Candlemas Day customs
If the groundhog sees his shadow, there will be 6 more weeks of winter
The movie 'Groundhog Day' made this holiday famous worldwide

title: Super Bowl Sunday
description: Get ready for the biggest sports event in America on Super Bowl Sunday! This unofficial American holiday brings families and friends together for football, food, and commercials. From the big game to the halftime show, Super Bowl Sunday is about more than just football - it's about community, tradition, and the American spirit of competition.
howToCelebrate: Host or attend a Super Bowl party with friends and family. Prepare traditional Super Bowl foods like wings, nachos, and chili. Watch the game, halftime show, and commercials. Participate in Super Bowl squares or other betting pools. Share your Super Bowl predictions and party photos on social media.
funFacts: Super Bowl Sunday is the second-largest food consumption day in America after Thanksgiving
Americans consume over 1.25 billion chicken wings on Super Bowl Sunday
The first Super Bowl was played in 1967 between the Packers and Chiefs
Super Bowl commercials cost millions of dollars for just 30 seconds
The halftime show has featured some of the biggest names in music

title: Mother's Day
description: Honor the amazing women who raised us on Mother's Day! This beloved American holiday celebrates mothers, grandmothers, and mother figures who have shaped our lives. From breakfast in bed to heartfelt cards, show your appreciation for the unconditional love, sacrifice, and guidance that mothers provide every day.
howToCelebrate: Spend quality time with your mother or mother figure. Give thoughtful gifts, cards, or flowers. Prepare a special meal or take her out to dinner. Call or video chat with your mom if you can't be together. Share memories and photos of your mother on social media.
funFacts: Mother's Day was officially established in 1914 by President Woodrow Wilson
Anna Jarvis created Mother's Day to honor her own mother
Americans spend over $25 billion on Mother's Day gifts each year
Mother's Day is celebrated in over 50 countries worldwide
The most popular Mother's Day gift is flowers, followed by greeting cards

title: Father's Day
description: Celebrate the dads who make a difference on Father's Day! This special American holiday honors fathers, grandfathers, and father figures who have guided, supported, and loved us. From grilling together to sharing stories, show your appreciation for the wisdom, strength, and love that fathers bring to our lives.
howToCelebrate: Spend time with your father doing activities he enjoys. Give thoughtful gifts like tools, books, or experiences. Cook a meal together or take him out to his favorite restaurant. Share stories and memories about your dad. Call or visit your father to show your appreciation.
funFacts: Father's Day was officially recognized as a national holiday in 1972
Sonora Smart Dodd created Father's Day to honor her Civil War veteran father
Americans spend about $16 billion on Father's Day gifts annually
The most popular Father's Day gifts are greeting cards and clothing
Father's Day is celebrated on different dates in different countries

title: Cinco de Mayo
description: ¡Viva México! Celebrate Cinco de Mayo, the vibrant American-Mexican cultural celebration! While it commemorates Mexico's victory at the Battle of Puebla, in the US it has become a celebration of Mexican culture, heritage, and community. From tacos and margaritas to music and dancing, embrace the festive spirit of this beloved American holiday.
howToCelebrate: Enjoy Mexican food and drinks at local restaurants or make them at home. Attend Cinco de Mayo festivals and parades in your community. Learn about Mexican history and culture. Wear traditional Mexican colors and decorations. Share your Cinco de Mayo celebrations on social media.
funFacts: Cinco de Mayo commemorates Mexico's victory over France in 1862
It's more widely celebrated in the US than in Mexico
Americans consume over 80 million pounds of avocados on Cinco de Mayo
The largest Cinco de Mayo celebration is in Los Angeles
Cinco de Mayo is not Mexico's Independence Day (that's September 16)
